title: Tanzania: Dar Plans Ten-Year Strategy to Harness Unemployment
text:
Africa: Human Trafficking Seen Escalating By Alvar Mwakyusa 
AS it seeks to lessen unemployment rate in the country, the government plans to establish a 10-year National Skills Development Strategy aimed at grooming graduating students to become job creators rather than seekers. 
The initiative aims at fast tracking implementation of existing policies on unemployment, which despite their existence, have done little to tackle the issue. 
"The government realizes hurdles faced by youth seeking jobs in the labour market and thus the initiative will enable graduates to engage in self employment," the Director of Labour in the Ministry of Labour and Employment, Mr Ally Msaki, revealed. 
Mr Msaki made the remarks on the sidelines of a workshop on unemployment and challenges of the labour market organized jointly by Economic and Social Research Foundation (ESRF) and Canada's International Development Research Centre (IDRC). 
"The course of action for the envisaged strategy is undergoing; the aim of the government is to enhance productivity by ensuring that students are provided with required skills for the labour market," he explained. 
The Director added further that, "The current education system hardly enables graduates to be self-employed but through the strategy we aim at making that possible." At the same occasion, a senior researcher at ESRF, Prof Fortunata Makene, said the think-tank will continue conducting research and make recommendations on addressing unemployment rate in Tanzania. 
The researcher was also quick to add that the existing policies could have done a great job in reducing the number of jobless youth if they were effectively implemented by respective institutions. 
"Available statistics show that 13 per cent of the youth in the world are unemployed and many in employment are forced into indecent jobs; in East Africa, studies have indicated that graduates in the region lack skills required by the labour market," the don explained. 
Prof Makene hinted as well that more studies will be conducted on how the youth can be groomed to make good use of skills and talents required for the dynamic labour market. Tanzania
